channel.title: tastytrade: Options Jive
channel.description: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Learn to talk the talk - sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss trading topics of the day.
channel.itunes:author: tastytrade

channel.googleplay:author: tastytrade, Inc.

item.title: Oddly Large Vol Contractions
item.description: Friday’s move in cash VIX represented the top 1% of VIX declines since 1990. Friday’s move in the S&P 500 index was unusually small given the move in volatility: 90% of those 1% VIX down moves saw a bigger move in the stock market than we saw on Friday.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

item.title: What Happens to Options in a Buyout?
item.description:
A buyout is a term used to describe a merger between two companies. Usually, a buyout results in the acquiring company being dissolved. So what happens if you have an options position in a company that is being acquired?

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they look at various buyout scenarios and what to expect for your option positions.

item.title: IV From Top to Bottom
item.description: As traders, we can use the three measures of IV to gauge the following information: 1. a stock’s expected annual range, 2. a stock’s expected range over a certain time period, and 3. the perceived risk of reaching a certain price over a certain period. The values of 1. and 2. are derived from 3., and 3. is derived from pure market forces which is the best and only way to gauge the actual, tradable risk of an underlying.

item.title: Distribution of Losses
item.description: tastytraders stick to trades with high probability of profit, but losses still sometimes happen. Today, Tom and Tony look at the data to see what kind of losses we should be prepared for when trades go wrong.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: tastytraders stick to trades with high probability of profit, but losses still sometimes happen. Today, Tom and Tony look at the data to see what kind of losses we should be prepared for when trades go wrong.

item.title: Calm Before the Storm
item.description:
August 2021 has seen volatility measures abate as the S&P 500 has reached new highs almost on a daily basis. The index has swung an average of 0.5% each day in August and could become the calmest month since November 2019. Is this the new normal? Or is volatility ahead?

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they analyze whether the recent calm in the markets portend a storm of volatility ahead.

item.title: What is the Volatility Surface?
item.description: Implied volatility is not a known quantity--it must be calculated from the prices of individual options. This volatility can be calculated using different arbitrage constraints and finding a volatility surface that best fits the real world data. Today, Tom, Tony and Alex discuss this process of calculating implied volatility, and the theory behind volatility and option pricing.

item.title: Probabilities Through Time
item.description: Sticking to high probability of profit trades is an important ingredient to reliably growing an account, but sometimes there are periods when losses cluster. Today, Tom and Tony look at how probabilities of profit have played out over the years and how reliably profitable trades turn into profitable months.

item.title: Six Charts That Matter Right Now
item.description:
With 86% of the S&P 500 having reported earnings, one would think the market would be headed for a small recess into the summer doldrums prior to Labor Day. However, there are some compelling stories out there in the form of charts.

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as glance at the six charts that matter right now in the market.

item.title: Poor Man's Covered Option
item.description: A Poor Man’s Covered Option (PMCO) is an alternative to a covered stock and requires less capital to construct. We can use Calls or Puts. Join Tom and Tony today as they explain this strategy.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: A Poor Man’s Covered Option (PMCO) is an alternative to a covered stock and requires less capital to construct. We can use Calls or Puts. Join Tom and Tony today as they explain this strategy.

item.title: Backtesting Short Puts and Covered Calls on lookback
item.description:
We have previously done studies comparing short put and covered call performance with SPY, a fairly bullish underlying.

However, how do these strategies compare for underlyings that have not been consistently bullish (e.g. XLE and TWTR)?

Join Tom, Tony, and Julia as they use lookback to answer this question.

item.title: Volatility Comes Down
item.description: tastytraders rely on the fact that when IVR is high, IV is likely to come down given enough time. Today, Tom and Tony examine how IV has behaved in different IVR environments and compare the differences between ETF and equities.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: tastytraders rely on the fact that when IVR is high, IV is likely to come down given enough time. Today, Tom and Tony examine how IV has behaved in different IVR environments and compare the differences between ETF and equities.

item.title: The Chinese Regulatory Conundrum
item.description:
For over two decades, Chinese tech companies got around restrictive listing rules by taking shares public on U.S. exchanges. Now, Chinese policymakers want more control. What does this mean for Chinese stocks?

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they take a look at the regulatory conundrum for U.S.-listed Chinese companies.

item.title: Market Moves Post-Earnings
item.description: While market and earnings moves are unpredictable, some underlyings are highly correlated. Often times when one stock moves up after earnings, market observers expect the same to be found across its sector. We analyzed the past four years of quarterly earnings in major tech companies to see if the market reaction is in fact correlated.

item.title: 2-Sided Rolling for Defined Risk Trades
item.description: For undefined risk trades, we’ve learned that what starts as a strangle, comes off as a strangle. Does this same rule apply to Iron Condors? Today, Tom and Tony examine the data to see if we can benefit from whipsaw markets by rolling the wings of Iron Condors separately.
